title: Introducing: Souvenir
content:
There was this soft and glorious era, sometime in the early noughties, when coloured leaves leapt and danced in flurries on breezy gusts across our Converse’d feet.

Real responsibility was in short supply, but hormones did a great job at filling the space. Taking Back Sunday were still incredible. Minus the Bear were the height of sophistication in rock music. Things meant a lot.

There was a boom, and there was a bust, like anything else. And now that the dust has long settled, it’s about time to go tomb raidin’. Turns out the man for the job is one Martin Ruffin, helmsman of twiddly, floaty, pop-punk three piece Souvenir (as well as one fifth of South Coast noise bastards The James Cleaver Quintet, and the sole force behind the breathtaking In Lieu), whose debut release Notes From Underground exhibits all of the virtues and none of the vices associated with their particular musical pathway. Songs like Shades of Hades and Quiz Kid Donnie Smith pump their figurative fists with all the energy and conviction of sweepy-haired adolescents, but temper their abandon with a healthy dose of tech born from experience and hard work. Likewise, closer Troy is possessed of a beauty and complexity wholly at odds with traditional preconceptions of punk rock.

We all have our time in hell. But it can still sound like a whole bunch of goddamn fun. Please visit the Gift Shop on your way out.
author: 5e9b68b27a1236eccfeb1d3c
